When time is limited, it's essential to set realistic goals for your skateboarding practice. Start by assessing how much time you can realistically allocate to skateboarding each day or week. It could be as little as 15 minutes or as much as an hour. Once you have a clear idea of the time you can commit, set achievable goals based on that timeframe. Remember, progress is progress, no matter how small.

2. Create a Schedule

To make the most of your limited time, create a schedule specifically for skateboarding. Treat it as you would any other important appointment or commitment. Block off dedicated time slots in your calendar and stick to them. By having a set schedule, you'll be more likely to follow through and prioritize your skateboarding practice.

3. Utilize Short Bursts of Time

Even if you can't find large chunks of time for skateboarding, take advantage of short bursts throughout your day. Utilize your lunch breaks, early mornings, or evenings to squeeze in a quick skate session. Carry your skateboard with you, and whenever you have a spare moment, find a nearby skate spot or practice your skills in an empty parking lot.

4. Find Skateboarding Communities

Joining skateboarding communities can be incredibly beneficial for busy individuals. These communities often organize events, meetups, or skate sessions. By connecting with fellow skateboarders, you can learn from their experiences and gain insights into effective time management strategies. Additionally, being part of a community can provide motivation and accountability to keep pushing forward.

5. Focus on Fundamental Skills

When time is limited, it's crucial to prioritize the fundamental skills of skateboarding. Mastering the basics will not only build a strong foundation but also make learning more advanced tricks easier in the long run. Focus on skills like balance, pushing, turning, and stopping. By dedicating your limited time to these essential skills, you'll progress steadily and gain confidence on the board.

6. Embrace Technology

Technology can be your ally when it comes to skateboarding. There are numerous skateboarding tutorial videos available online that can help you learn and practice new tricks. Take advantage of these resources during your downtime or when you can't physically be on your skateboard. Watching tutorials and visualizing the movements can enhance your understanding and make your practice sessions more effective.

7. Make Skateboarding a Priority

Ultimately, overcoming time constraints requires making skateboarding a priority in your life. Evaluate your daily activities and identify areas where you can make adjustments. It may mean sacrificing some leisure time or rearranging your schedule, but remember that pursuing your passion is worth the effort. By consciously making skateboarding a priority, you'll find creative ways to fit it into your busy lifestyle.

Skateboarding should never be seen as an obstacle in your busy life but rather as an opportunity for personal growth and enjoyment. By setting realistic goals, creating a schedule, utilizing short bursts of time, finding communities, focusing on fundamental skills, embracing technology, and making skateboarding a priority, you can overcome time constraints and embark on an incredible skateboarding journey.

title: Overcoming Skateboarding Anxiety: Conquer Fear of Solo Sessions
barrier: I'm afraid of doing things alone
content:
Skateboarding is an exhilarating sport that offers a unique blend of creativity, freedom, and athleticism. For those who are eager to get started but find themselves plagued by the fear of doing things alone, overcoming skateboarding anxiety can be a daunting task. However, with the right mindset and a few helpful strategies, anyone can conquer their fear of solo sessions and embark on an exciting skateboarding journey.

1. Start with the Basics

One of the most effective ways to ease into skateboarding and build confidence is by starting with the basics. Begin by familiarizing yourself with the skateboard itself – spend some time standing on it, getting comfortable with its dimensions and weight. Practice balancing on the board while stationary, gradually increasing the duration as you feel more at ease.

2. Find a Skateboarding Community

Skateboarding doesn't have to be a solitary pursuit. Joining a skateboarding community can provide immense support and encouragement. Seek out local skate parks, skate shops, or online forums where you can connect with other skateboarders who share similar fears and experiences. Engaging with like-minded individuals can help alleviate anxiety and provide a sense of camaraderie.

3. Take Baby Steps

Conquering fear is a gradual process, and it's essential to take baby steps. Start by practicing in a safe and controlled environment, such as an empty parking lot or a smooth pavement area. Begin with simple movements like pushing off and maintaining balance. As you gain confidence, gradually progress to more challenging maneuvers and tricks.

4. Visualize Success

Visualization is a powerful tool that can help overcome fear and anxiety. Spend some time visualizing yourself successfully performing skateboarding tricks and maneuvers. Imagine the feeling of accomplishment and the joy of conquering your fears. By visualizing success, you can rewire your brain to associate skateboarding with positive outcomes, reducing anxiety in the process.

5. Seek Professional Guidance

If you're struggling to overcome skateboarding anxiety, seeking professional guidance can make a significant difference. Enroll in skateboarding lessons or hire a skateboarding coach who can provide personalized instruction and support. A professional can help you develop proper technique, build confidence, and overcome any mental barriers you may be facing.

6. Embrace Failure as a Learning Opportunity

It's important to remember that failure is an integral part of the learning process. Every skateboarder, regardless of their skill level, experiences falls and setbacks. Instead of letting fear of failure paralyze you, embrace it as an opportunity to learn and grow. Each time you fall, dust yourself off, analyze what went wrong, and use that knowledge to improve for the next attempt.

7. Celebrate Small Victories

As you progress in your skateboarding journey, remember to celebrate even the smallest victories. Whether it's successfully landing a trick, conquering a fear, or simply spending more time on your board, acknowledge and reward your achievements. Celebrating these milestones will boost your confidence and motivate you to continue pushing past your fears.

Overcoming skateboarding anxiety is no easy feat, but with determination, patience, and the right strategies, it is entirely possible. By starting with the basics, finding support within a community, taking small steps, visualizing success, seeking guidance, embracing failure, and celebrating victories, you can conquer your fear of solo sessions and unlock the thrilling world of skateboarding.

title: Overcoming Triathlon Fears: Conquer Injury Anxiety
content:
Triathlon is an exhilarating sport that combines swimming, cycling, and running into one challenging event. For those wanting to embark on this journey, it is natural to have fears, especially when it comes to the risk of getting injured. However, with the right mindset and preparation, you can conquer these fears and confidently dive into the world of multi-sport racing. Here are some steps to help you overcome your injury anxiety:

1. Start Slow and Build a Strong Foundation

One of the best ways to prevent injuries is to gradually build your endurance and fitness level. Begin with shorter distances and gradually increase your training volume and intensity. This approach allows your body to adapt and reduces the risk of overuse injuries.

2. Seek Professional Guidance

Working with a certified triathlon coach or joining a triathlon training group can provide invaluable guidance and support. These professionals can help you develop a structured training plan tailored to your abilities and help you learn proper technique and form, minimizing the risk of injury.

3. Listen to Your Body

It's crucial to listen to your body and recognize the difference between discomfort and pain. Pushing through pain can lead to more significant injuries. If you experience persistent pain or discomfort, it's essential to rest and seek advice from a medical professional.

4. Cross-Train and Strengthen Your Body

Engaging in cross-training activities such as yoga, strength training, and flexibility exercises can help improve your overall fitness and reduce the risk of overuse injuries. Strengthening your core muscles, in particular, can provide stability and support during the swim, bike, and run portions of a triathlon.

5. Gradually Increase Intensity and Distance

As you become more comfortable with your training, gradually increase the intensity and distance of your workouts. This progressive approach allows your body to adapt and reduces the risk of sudden injuries caused by pushing too hard, too soon.

6. Proper Nutrition and Hydration

Fueling your body with the right nutrients and staying properly hydrated is crucial for both performance and injury prevention. Consult with a sports nutritionist to develop a nutrition plan that meets your specific needs and supports your training goals.

7. Rest and Recovery

Rest and recovery are just as important as training. Make sure to schedule regular rest days and incorporate recovery techniques such as foam rolling, stretching, and massage into your routine. Adequate rest allows your body to repair and rebuild, reducing the risk of overuse injuries.

8. Set Realistic Goals

Setting realistic goals based on your current fitness level and capabilities can help alleviate anxiety about getting injured. Work with your coach or trainer to establish achievable goals that push you just enough without overwhelming you.

9. Embrace a Positive Mindset

Triathlon requires mental strength as much as physical strength. Cultivate a positive mindset and focus on the joy of the journey rather than fixating on potential injuries. Visualize yourself crossing the finish line strong and injury-free, and let that image drive you forward.

Remember, while the fear of injury is valid, it should not hold you back from pursuing your triathlon dreams. By following these steps and taking a methodical approach to training, you can conquer your injury anxiety and confidently dive into the world of multi-sport racing. Embrace the challenge, trust the process, and enjoy the incredible journey that triathlon has to offer!

title: Overcoming Triathlon Boredom: Igniting Motivation for Beginners
content:
Triathlon is a challenging sport that combines swimming, cycling, and running. It requires immense physical and mental strength, making it an exhilarating experience for athletes. However, for beginners, the journey towards becoming a triathlete can sometimes feel tedious and boring. The monotony of training sessions and the lack of immediate progress can dampen motivation. But fear not, overcoming triathlon boredom is possible with the right strategies and mindset. Here are some effective tips to ignite motivation and keep the flame burning for beginners:

1. Set Realistic Goals

One of the main reasons why beginners may feel bored or demotivated is because their goals are too ambitious or unrealistic. It's essential to set achievable goals that align with your current fitness level and experience. Start by breaking down your ultimate triathlon goal into smaller milestones. Celebrate each milestone you achieve, as it will boost your motivation and keep you engaged in the process.

2. Mix Up Your Training Sessions

Repeating the same training routine can quickly lead to boredom. To combat this, incorporate variety into your workouts. Instead of always swimming at the pool, consider open water swimming or joining a triathlon club for group sessions. Explore different cycling routes or try interval training to challenge yourself. Additionally, cross-training activities such as yoga or strength training can add a refreshing twist to your routine and help prevent burnout.

3. Find a Training Partner or Join a Community

Training alone can sometimes feel monotonous and isolating. Seek out like-minded individuals who share your passion for triathlon. Joining a triathlon club or finding a training partner can provide a sense of camaraderie, accountability, and motivation. Training with others will not only make your workouts more enjoyable but also provide an opportunity to learn from experienced athletes and gain valuable insights.

4. Track Your Progress

Keeping track of your progress is crucial for staying motivated. Use a training journal or a smartphone app to record your workouts, distances, and times. Seeing your improvements over time will help you stay focused and remind you of the progress you've made. Celebrate even the smallest achievements, as they are stepping stones towards your ultimate goal.

5. Mix Up Your Race Calendar

Participating in different races can help break the monotony and reignite your passion for triathlon. Explore various race distances, from sprint to Olympic to Ironman. Consider participating in different locations or even international races. The excitement of new race environments and the challenge of adapting to different courses will inject a fresh dose of motivation into your training.

6. Practice Mindfulness and Visualization

Triathlon is not just a physical sport; it's also a mental game. Incorporate mindfulness and visualization techniques into your training routine. Before each training session, take a few moments to clear your mind and focus on your goals. Visualize yourself successfully completing the race, crossing the finish line, and feeling a sense of accomplishment. This mental practice will help you stay motivated and overcome any boredom or self-doubt that may arise.

Remember, every triathlete, including the most accomplished ones, has faced moments of boredom and lack of motivation. The key is to acknowledge these feelings and take proactive steps to overcome them. By setting realistic goals, diversifying your training, seeking support from a community, tracking your progress, exploring new races, and practicing mindfulness, you can reignite your motivation and continue your journey towards becoming a successful triathlete. Embrace the challenges, stay focused, and enjoy the transformative experience that triathlon offers!

title: Triathlon Troubles? Get Started with These Simple Tips!
content:
Triathlon is an exhilarating sport that combines swimming, cycling, and running into one challenging event. If you're a beginner who wants to dive into the world of triathlons but feels overwhelmed, don't worry! We've got you covered with some simple tips to help you get started.

1. Set Clear Goals

Before you begin your triathlon journey, it's essential to set clear and achievable goals. Determine what distance you want to compete in and establish a realistic timeline for your training. This will give you a sense of direction and motivation throughout your triathlon preparation.

2. Start with a Training Plan

A well-structured training plan is crucial for triathlon success. Look for beginner-friendly plans that gradually increase your training volume and intensity. Make sure your plan includes specific workouts for each discipline – swimming, cycling, and running – as well as rest days for recovery.

3. Prioritize Consistency

Consistency is key when training for a triathlon. Aim to train regularly, even if it's just a few times a week. Consistent training builds endurance, improves technique, and helps prevent injuries. Remember, it's better to have shorter but frequent training sessions than sporadic long sessions.

4. Seek Professional Guidance

If you're struggling with the technical aspects of swimming, cycling, or running, consider seeking professional guidance. Join a triathlon club or hire a coach who can provide expert advice on proper form, training techniques, and race strategies. Their expertise will help you overcome any hurdles and progress faster.

5. Gradually Increase Intensity

When starting your triathlon training, it's important to gradually increase the intensity of your workouts. Pushing yourself too hard, too soon can lead to burnout or injuries. Listen to your body and give yourself time to adapt to the demands of the sport. Slowly increase the duration and intensity of your workouts as you build strength and endurance.

6. Practice Transitions

Transitions – the periods between each discipline – can make or break your triathlon performance. Practice transitioning smoothly from swimming to cycling and from cycling to running. Set up a mock transition area and rehearse your routine, including changing clothes, putting on shoes, and fueling up. Efficient transitions can save you valuable time during the race.

7. Embrace the Multisport Lifestyle

Triathlon is more than just a race; it's a lifestyle. Embrace the multisport community and connect with fellow triathletes. Attend local events, join online forums, and share your experiences. Surrounding yourself with like-minded individuals will provide support, encouragement, and valuable tips that will enhance your triathlon journey.

Remember, triathlon is a challenging sport, but with determination and the right guidance, you can overcome any troubles and achieve your triathlon goals. So, dive in, train hard, and enjoy the journey. The finish line awaits!

title: Overcoming Distractions: A Guide for Triathlon Beginners
content:
Triathlon is an exhilarating sport that combines swimming, cycling, and running into one ultimate challenge. For those who are new to the world of triathlons, it can be overwhelming to juggle the demands of training while dealing with distractions. However, with the right mindset and strategies, you can overcome these distractions and stay focused on your triathlon journey. Here are some helpful tips to get you started:

1. Set Clear Goals

Before diving into triathlon training, it's essential to establish clear goals that you want to achieve. Having a specific objective in mind will help you stay motivated and focused. Whether it's completing your first sprint triathlon or improving your overall performance, write down your goals and keep them visible as a constant reminder.

2. Create a Training Schedule

One of the biggest challenges for beginners is finding time to train. With busy schedules and numerous responsibilities, it's easy to get distracted. To overcome this, create a training schedule that fits your lifestyle. Allocate specific time slots for swimming, cycling, and running workouts, and treat them as non-negotiable appointments with yourself. By sticking to a consistent routine, you'll be less likely to get sidetracked.

3. Eliminate Distractions

When it's time to train, eliminate distractions as much as possible. Put your phone on silent or in another room, close unnecessary tabs on your computer, and let your family or roommates know that you need uninterrupted time. Creating a distraction-free environment will help you focus solely on your training and maximize your productivity.

4. Find an Accountability Partner

Having someone to hold you accountable can significantly increase your chances of staying focused. Find a training buddy or join a triathlon club where you can connect with like-minded individuals. By sharing your goals and progress with others, you'll feel a sense of responsibility to stay on track. Plus, training with others can make the journey more enjoyable and motivating.

5. Break it Down

Triathlon can be overwhelming, especially for beginners. Instead of focusing on the entire race at once, break it down into smaller, manageable goals. Set targets for each discipline and gradually increase the intensity and duration of your workouts. By taking it one step at a time, you'll build confidence and stay motivated throughout your training.

6. Practice Mindfulness

Distractions often arise from a cluttered mind. Practicing mindfulness techniques, such as meditation or deep breathing exercises, can help calm your thoughts and improve your focus. Dedicate a few minutes each day to quiet your mind and center yourself. This practice will not only benefit your triathlon training but also enhance your overall well-being.

7. Celebrate Small Victories

Triathlon is a challenging sport, and progress may not always come quickly. It's crucial to celebrate even the smallest victories along the way. Whether it's completing a challenging swim session or improving your cycling speed, acknowledge your accomplishments and reward yourself. Recognizing your achievements will boost your confidence and keep you motivated to overcome distractions.

Remember, distractions are a part of life, but they don't have to derail your triathlon journey. By setting clear goals, establishing a training schedule, eliminating distractions, finding accountability, breaking down the race, practicing mindfulness, and celebrating small victories, you'll be well on your way to overcoming distractions and achieving success in your triathlon endeavors. Stay focused, stay determined, and enjoy the rewarding experience of triathlon!

title: Finding ADHD Management
content:
Living with ADHD is a lifelong adaptation and condition that deserves your advocacy. By finding awareness in your ADHD and what works best for its management, you’ll unlock a happier and healthier relationship with the world around you. Take time to find coping strategies, so that you can live a life filled to the brim with opportunity.

Having ADHD means that you are a neurodivergent person, filled with individuality, creativity and energy that is ready to be cultivated. Neurodivergence refers to people whose brain develops or works differently than the typical person. This means that you have different strengths and struggles in development and expression. Celebrate your uniqueness!

Focus on the benefits of being you. People with ADHD report higher levels of social intelligence, humor, and recognition of feeling. This recognition is referred to as empathy, and trust us, this is a beautiful and rare gift! Your unique brain may have the ability to have a more positive mental approach, noticing everything around you and leading to more ‘social success’ with your peers.

Through your expansion of growth here at Brimming, you are finding new activities that bring you joy and better management of your ADHD symptoms. Some initial benefits include protecting and developing a healthy self-image and confidence.

You may also start to notice that you are making smarter choices for yourself long term, avoiding substance abuse, disruptive behaviors, and unhealthy intimate relationships. Celebrate each win, and start to track every success that you begin to notice through a journal or community-share.

title: Conquering Imposter Syndrome in American Football: A Guide for Beginners
content:
Imposter syndrome can be a challenging obstacle to overcome for anyone starting a new endeavor, and American Football is no exception. The feeling of inadequacy and self-doubt can be overwhelming, making it difficult to fully immerse oneself in the sport. However, with the right mindset and strategies, it is possible to conquer imposter syndrome and thrive in American Football.

1. Embrace the Learning Curves

Remember that everyone starts as a beginner. It is natural to feel like an imposter when you are just starting out, especially in a complex sport like American Football. Embrace the learning curve and accept that it will take time and effort to become proficient. Instead of focusing on what you don't know, celebrate every small victory and use each experience as an opportunity to learn and grow.

2. Seek Guidance from Experienced Players

Don't be afraid to ask for help. Reach out to experienced players, coaches, or mentors who can provide guidance and support. They have likely been through similar struggles and can offer valuable advice to help you overcome imposter syndrome. Joining a team or a league can also provide a supportive community where you can learn from others and gain confidence in your abilities.

3. Set Realistic Goals

Setting realistic goals can help you build confidence and track your progress. Break down your overall goal of becoming proficient in American Football into smaller, achievable milestones. Celebrate each milestone you reach, and use it as motivation to keep pushing forward. Remember, progress is a journey, and every step counts.

4. Focus on Your Strengths

Imposter syndrome often makes us hyper-aware of our weaknesses and shortcomings. Shift your focus to your strengths instead. Identify the areas in American Football where you excel and build upon them. By acknowledging and leveraging your strengths, you can boost your confidence and overcome the feeling of being an imposter.

5. Embrace Failure as a Learning Opportunity

Failure is an inevitable part of any learning process. Instead of letting it discourage you, view failure as an opportunity to learn and improve. Analyze your mistakes, seek feedback, and use that knowledge to enhance your skills. Remember, even the most accomplished players have faced setbacks. It is how you bounce back from failure that defines your growth.

6. Practice Mindfulness and Self-Compassion

Imposter syndrome can be fueled by negative self-talk and self-criticism. Practice mindfulness and self-compassion to counteract these thoughts. Be kind to yourself and acknowledge that everyone has their own unique journey. Treat yourself with the same kindness and understanding you would offer to a friend facing similar challenges.

7. Celebrate Your Progress

Lastly, take the time to celebrate your progress, no matter how small it may seem. Recognize and appreciate the effort you put into learning American Football. Celebrate your achievements, whether it's mastering a new technique, scoring a touchdown, or simply showing up and giving your best. Remember, every step forward is a step closer to conquering imposter syndrome and becoming a confident player.

Conquering imposter syndrome in American Football is not an overnight process, but with perseverance and the right mindset, it is achievable. Embrace the journey, seek support, and celebrate your progress along the way. Remember, you belong on the field, and your dedication and passion for the sport will shine through.

title: Decoding American Football: Simplifying Terminology for Novice Players
barrier: I don't understand all these new terms
content:
American football is a thrilling and popular sport that captivates millions of fans across the United States. However, for those who are new to the game, understanding the terminology can be a daunting task. From plays and positions to penalties and formations, there seems to be a never-ending list of unfamiliar terms and jargon.

With a little patience and some guidance, you can easily navigate through the maze of American football terminology and begin enjoying the game to its fullest. Here are some steps to help you overcome the initial hurdle of learning new terms:

Start with the basics

Like any new endeavor, it's essential to build a strong foundation. Begin by familiarizing yourself with the fundamental terms commonly used in American football. These include terms like touchdown, field goal, offense, defense, quarterback, and wide receiver. Understanding these basic concepts will provide you with a solid starting point.

Utilize reliable resources

Take advantage of the wealth of resources available to help you learn and understand American football terminology. Online tutorials, videos, and guides specifically designed for beginners can be incredibly helpful. These resources often break down complex terms into simple explanations, making it easier for you to grasp the concepts.

Watch and learn

One of the most effective ways to familiarize yourself with American football terminology is by watching games. Pay attention to the commentators' explanations and analysis during the game. They often provide insights into the strategies, plays, and terms being used. Additionally, observing the players on the field and their actions can help reinforce your understanding of the terminology.

Ask questions

Don't be afraid to seek clarification when you come across a term you don't understand. Reach out to friends, family, or fellow football enthusiasts who have a good grasp of the game. They can help explain unfamiliar terms and provide context that will enhance your overall understanding.

Break it down

When faced with complex terms, try breaking them down into smaller, more manageable parts. For example, if you encounter the term "zone defense," break it down into "zone" and "defense." Then, research and understand each component separately before putting them together. This approach will simplify the learning process and make it easier to remember.

Practice makes perfect

As with any skill, practice is key to mastering American football terminology. Engage in conversations about the sport, participate in online forums or local football communities, and join or form a beginner's league. The more you immerse yourself in the world of American football, the more comfortable you will become with the terminology.

Embrace the learning process, be patient with yourself, and celebrate each small victory along the way. With time and dedication, you'll find yourself speaking the language of American football fluently, and the game will become even more enjoyable as a result!

title: Top Benefit of Yoga - Increased Self Awareness
content:
What is Self-Awareness? Self-Awareness is the conscious knowledge of your feelings, desires, and motives. This can expand to include knowledge of your physical body, character, and demeanor; How do you carry yourself? How do you move through this world? There are many incredible benefits to starting your Yoga practice, but one that you might notice right away is your increased self-awareness. This awareness might start in a more negative talk, and that’s OK! If you are worried about what you are wearing, how you look while practicing yoga, getting there on time and where to practice yoga, then you are showing many signs that you are incredibly self-aware. This is a great starting point that most practitioners share with you. Being self-aware means that you care immensely, so any nervousness or internal chatter experienced is a reflection of how much effort and time you’re putting into this activity, and you should be proud of this. It’s time to harness this energy and effort and translate it to something positive that will benefit you for a lifetime!

In time, this negative self-awareness will shift into a more positive one, as you start to become aware of the people around you as well as your physical body. Let’s start with your physical body awareness. By practicing yoga, you will start to notice the difference between your left and right sides, and any asymmetry that you might have in your body that might help you troubleshoot chronic pain that you have been experiencing lately. It is incredibly beneficial to discover the source of your physical pain, and this is often discovered in movement. You will become aware of what poses are significantly more challenging for you, and get to explore why exactly they are challenging for you; is it due to a lack of breath, flexibility or balance? Is there a part of the body that you should cater to, like a previous injury or surgery that is holding you back? Be sure to let your Yoga Teacher know of any injuries, pains, or if you are pregnant so that they can adapt the practice to suit your needs. There are many fellow students that are practicing with the same aches and pains and will benefit from your own personal self-awareness and needs on the mat.

In addition to your awareness of your physical body, you will become increasingly self-aware of how you engage with others around you. Becoming respectful in your Yoga practice means placing your mat in a kind and compassionate way that works for you as well as your Yoga neighbor, eliminating loud conversations so that you can enjoy the quiet solitude of your Yoga practice, and knowing that others are practicing the same level of self-awareness with their voice volume, their odors. It is mutually beneficial to address the distractions that everyone can bring to the mat, like a cell phone or watch, and remove as many distractions as possible to enhance your sense of community. While it might be overwhelming at first, it’s important to celebrate the new awareness and discoveries that you find when you start your Yoga practice.

title: What to Expect After Your First Yoga Practice
content:
Look at you! It’s time to celebrate your practice; you are fully submerging yourself into the world of yoga and have done the dang thing! First and foremost, give yourself a pat on the back and be proud of your hard work for arriving onto the mat and giving this discipline ago. We see your hard work, and you deserve to check the box.

Your physical body is likely sore from the movement and exploration of your body, as you have likely been doing movements and poses that you have never done before. Be sure to take care of yourself, and decide whether you need a few days off in between your yoga practice, or to take a gentle approach to practice in Lieu of injuring yourself and pushing your limits. Instead of no pain no gain, it’s time to embrace no pain, no pain. Take note of which muscles are sore, if you have ever been sore there before, and if you are experiencing soreness versus pain or pulled muscles. We did not come to yoga to injure ourselves!

With the reflection of yoga, you may start to notice if you are her moments. Some of the lessons and themes that were presented in your yoga class will start to peer in your every day life. Take note of these magical synchronicities, for they will continue to guide you on this journey. You may notice that the things you are working on personally will also be reflected in your loved ones or your workplace. I building a yoga practice, and you are building a stronger connection to the world around you, and it is important to know the commonalities that we all have together. This is a unifying practice, and it is common for you to start noticing that you are more alike than you think. Some of the challenges that you see on the mat may be reflected off of the mat, like driving, mindfulness, and themes. Whether you like to journal or use journaling, it’s time to know what similarities you start to discover.

By expanding your physical muscles, the Yogi‘s would argue that you are expanding your mind just as much. By stretching the muscles of the body we stretch the muscles and dexterity of the mind and this is the intended purpose of yoga. If you ever start to feel overwhelmed mentally by this practice, be proud that you have noticed and take a step back and focus on furthering your awareness with a few of our articles and courses. If you find yourself hooked on this practice and can’t seem to get enough, implementing realistic yoga goals will help you stay on track. Is it more sustainable for you to practice two days a week, or up to six days a week? There should always be one day off from your practice to let the muscles in mind enjoy the benefits of practice.

title: Creativity Written in the Stars
content:
“There is a vitality, a life force, an energy, a quickening, that is translated through you into action, and because there is only one of you in all time, this expression is unique. And if you block it, it will never exist through any other medium and will be lost.” -Martha Graham

We are all creative. We are all here, in part, to allow for this unique expression, to leave an imprint of it. The idea that we are all creative usually brings up a variety of emotions and responses, the most typical being: maybe you are (or those artists over there are), but I am not.

As your faithful Brimming guide, I am here to assure you: yes you are!

We all have a way that creativity, as the pure creative energy of Life, is expressed through us. This looks different for each one of us (and probably even looks different for each of us as individuals at different times of our lives). One of the most helpful ways we can tune into our unique expression is (you guessed it!) through astrology and your birth chart. And, in fact, the practice of astrology is one that’s creative in its essence.

To learn and apply astrology is a unique mixture of left-brain analytics and right-brain creative analysis. Astrology is much more than memorizing definitions of each planet and sign, just as  no one is simply a sum of their planetary placement’s definitions.  However, it’s in our engagement with these energies that allows for creative, intuitive, and deductive thought. There is creativity needed in how we connect the information that exists within the chart, to see it as a living and breathing expression of energy.

When it comes to your own birth chart, there are two placements I look to first for creativity: your Moon and Venus.

Your Moon is an expression of your internal life and voice, your heart, your emotions (and how you process them) and shows us how creativity comes through you. Of course, all context of the Moon is important (sign, house, aspects, etc.) to seeing this expression on an individual level - certain aspects and placements will greatly shift the expression of the Moon.

Paying attention to the element and modality of your Moon placement will also give lots of clues. Have the Moon in a Fire sign? Your expression likely comes through in great bursts of energy, is rooted in  passion, desires to be visible, and is maybe even inspiring or calling others to action. Having the Moon in an Air sign gives a more cognitive quality to your creativity, maybe coming through in writing, communicating, sharing thoughts and ideas, and creating meaningful connections with others. The Moon in a Water sign gives a greater emphasis on the expression of creativity for catharsis and emotional healing/release - someone with this Moon placement may be more drawn to mediums like painting, poetry, or other non-linear forms. Moon placements in Earth signs seek a more grounded, practical expression of the Self and their creativity, perhaps through the body or in their physical environment.

Similarly, the Venus placement will also give further indication in regards to our creativity. In general, Venus relates more closely to our creative expression, sense of aesthetic, sensuality, beauty, art, and connection with others. Where your Venus resides will give you information about where your creativity resides, where/how it wants to be expressed, and how you feel fulfilled in regards to this expression.

There is so much validation, inspiration, and permission in tuning into these placements within your creative practice. When we lean into these placements - and allow for ourselves to express in the ways that feel natural to us, for our own unique expression to come through and be seen - we experience the pure energy of Life to move through us.

Remember that you are creative. In the words of my creativity doula, screenwriter/director/author Julia Cameron, “there is an underlying, in-dwelling creative force infusing all of life - including ourselves. We are, ourselves, creations. And we, in turn, are meant to continue creativity by being creative ourselves.”

title: Language Used in Yoga
content:
When starting your Yoga practice, you may notice a plethora of new terms that you have never heard before. Not only are you working with a new set of words in this activity, but you also hear a different language being used! Many Yoga practitioners and teachers use Sanskrit, which is an inactive and ancient language that has roots in the history of Yoga and its origin country of India.  If the Sanskrit language does not resonate with you, don’t worry! Yoga practices have been westernized and modernized to better understand the terms and descriptors used when practicing yoga, but it is common for you to hear a few Sanskrit words throughout your class. Here are a few terms that you will hear in any foundational yoga class:

The intention of Namaste is to honor the student and teacher relationship, and can translate to mean, ‘The light and teacher in me is honored to guide the light and teacher in you’. The intention behind saying Namaste is to honor that everyone is walking the same path. Rather than putting your teacher on a pedestal, or looking at students as beginners, the philosophy of Yoga asks us to view the student and teacher on the same path, as the teacher is forever a student to the practice, and the students have so much to teach one another. You often hear Namaste said and celebrated at the end of a yoga practice, to honor that everyone in the room is always learning and practicing, and no one is better than anyone else in the room.

Savasana-  translated to mean corpse pose, the Sanskrit term is used to describe just that: resting in peace.  The goal of this pose is to relax and unclench on muscles in the physical body, relax the eyes, and just be. While some students fall asleep, others have an active mind during this pose and it’s important to let the bodies stay still to find calmness and relaxation. There is nothing else to do, think, or exert when you are in this meditative posture. You’ll lie like a corpse for up to 3 to 5 minutes to feel the benefits of your hard work that you just put into your practice.

This posture is most often practiced at the end of your Yoga practice. The practitioner lies flat on their back, with their legs extended and their arms by their sides with palms faced up. Savasana requires mental and physical relaxation, and this pose can accompany a range of challenges and emotions. Some days, your expression of Savasana can be the most challenging pose of the practice, as the mind and body do not want to remain still. Other days, this pose is welcomed with ease and the practitioner feels immense relaxation and relief from their rigorous Yoga practice. Sometimes, the practitioner can fall asleep. This is okay! There is immense purpose of this pose, and many Yogis argue that is pose is non-negotiable. Savasana is meant to practice the in-between of a conscious and unconscious state. This practice of relaxing in the inbetween of consciousness has been proven to improve your sleep cycle, with practice making it easier long term to fall asleep quicker. In Savasana, it is important to avoid loud noises and distractions to the very best of your ability, as calming music or silence is welcomed during this pose to avoid distraction. Removing all perceived obstacles and distractions prior to Savasana so that the entirety of this pose can be experienced. Symbolizing death and improving the practitioner’s relationship with the human experience of the death and life cycle, becoming at ease and familiar with this concept. 

Phrase: ‘On the mat’-  most yoga poses that you will take will be practiced on your yoga mat, and you may have noticed that throughout this course your time is referred to as the mat. Your yoga mat is the rectangular shape that you’ll practice on top of, but can also refer to a beach towel, blanket, or a metaphorical sense. When you arrive on the mat, for example you are arriving to practice yoga and focus on yourself for the next few postures taken.

OM/Aum- many traditional yoga studios will incorporate an OM throughout class, which is a loud vibrational sound that is spoken or sung aloud. Whether you participate in this sacred sound or not is up to you, some students just enjoy listening to the sound of Om and others like to belted out and enjoy the effects of it using their voice, as it is one of the few opportunities that your voice is used in practice. The meaning of OM translates as a mantra symbolizing the union of mind, body, and spirit that is found by practicing yoga.

You may have noticed that Yoga is referred to as a Practice. According to definition, practice is the customary, habitual way of doing something. A repeated exercise in or performance of an activity or skill so as to acquire or maintain proficiency in it. To carry out or perform regularly. The intention behind referring to Yoga as a practice is to acknowledge that Yoga can never be mastered, but rather, practiced for a lifetime. There is not an end-goal of graduating from Yoga, or becoming the best in Yoga. Rather, committing to Yoga is a lifelong practice, where competition and hierarchy is absent. When referring to Yoga as a practice, the practitioner is able to enjoy the journey, rather than a perceived destination. Regardless of the external factors that are found outside of your Yoga class, we choose to show up and practice anyway. While advancement in flexibility is a result of practicing Yoga, ultimately, it is not the goal. Learning to accept your body exactly how it is will be the foundational root of your practice, and this radical self-acceptance serves us when we are sick, injured and aging. We meet ourselves where we are at, rather than forcing ourselves to where we perceive we want to be.

title: Yoga - Top Barrier - Perceived Limitations
content:
You may have heard a familiar sentiment (or even felt it yourself)! I can't do Yoga; I'm not flexible! While this feeling is valid, it also confirms why Yoga is actually perfect for you: Yoga is practiced to help increase flexibility in the body. You aren't too dirty to shower, right? While physical flexibility isn't required to practice Yoga, mental flexibility is. As you begin to open your mind to the healing practice of Yoga, your mental dexterity will help you understand that Yoga is intended for everyone, regardless of perceived physical limitations.

Many students are prescribed Yoga from their doctor, therapist, and loved ones. Regardless of the affliction, whether it be tight calves from running, anxiety from a heavy workload, or panic attacks that cause breathlessness, Yoga is a remedy for all. And because of this cure-all mentality, flexibility of the mind will help you wrap your head around the infinite possibilities that Yoga offers you. Rather than skipping your Yoga practice because of a broken ankle, for example, you will learn how to practice mindfulness and flexibility with Yoga while physically limited. Whether you are overweight, injured, or living with a lifelong condition, Yoga is meant to be adapted to your unique needs. This adaptation requires effort and attention. By crafting your Yoga practice around your unique needs, you'll be able to practice Yoga for life! Whether you are getting older, expecting a child, or dealing with a cold, you can find healing and possibility in your Yoga practice. By shifting your perspective around Yoga, you'll shift your ability of the physical body, too.

Yoga means to yoke. The goal is to yoke, or blend, your mind and body together as one in harmony, and intentional movement helps integrate our most powerful skills of body and mind. There are days when our mental state may hold us back, and other days when our physical body has its limitations. Rather than skipping Yoga, we choose to show up and practice anyway. The current state of the body and mind should not be ignored; Yoga should never be painful, and one should never push through the pain to find inner peace. Rather, by paying attention to how the body and mind moves, the practitioner is able to truly address what the body needs and grow in awareness of how to cater to what the day brings. Let's use an example of physical limitations and how it is addressed, modified and adapted in a Yoga practice:

Knee Complications

Knee injuries and surgeries are common in this lifetime! If bearing weight on your knees is not for you, then any Yoga pose taken on the knees can be adapted to off-the-knee. For example, Cat and Cow Pose (link to this foundational pose in your course HERE) is traditionally taken on the hands and knees. Well, tradition never addressed a torn ACL from running a marathon last year, now did it? While it can be frustrating to take the pose a little differently from 'everyone else' in class, that is the epitome of practicing Yoga. This is a practice of the self, not to be compared with your fellow Yogi neighbor. Cat and cow pose can be adopted by: tucking the toes and fully hovering the knees off the mat. This pose can be taken in a seat, fully removing any weight bearing on the knee. Cat and cow can be taken with the imagination, or the third eye, where you visualize your body taking the pose while aligning your breath with the imagery in front of you. And of course, a folded blanket can be placed underneath your knee. While it can be annoying or cumbersome to add a blanket as a prop initially, it will become second nature to you with practice and consistency. You are worth the 3 seconds it takes to slide a blanket underneath you, sit upright in a chair, or even choose to skip the pose.

Even 'Skipping' a Yoga pose, or choosing not to take it with your physical body, is still practicing Yoga. See, I told you to have a flexible mind! By addressing the needs of your body, discerning that you should not take a pose that will cause you trouble, and breathing through the moment while others take the pose, you are practicing Yoga beautifully! You are meant to be fully mindful and aware of the body's needs, and more often than not, Yoga teaches us what we don't like, and what does not work for us. With practice, this will become less frustrating and more exciting to adapt any pose to your personal needs. With practice, your Yoga practice will become more accessible. Yes, the pose should be sensational, but it should never be painful. In Yoga, you will learn to discern between this sensation verses pain.

Celebrate your arrival to this moment! By taking a Yoga Course, trying something new, and opening your mind to possibility, you are right where you need to be. Reading this article has furthered your understanding of Yoga practice, and that is worth observing and praising.

title: Styles of Yoga
content:
1. Hatha Yoga - a branch of Yoga which uses physical techniques to channel and preserve the vital force or energy, Hatha can be translated to mean ‘force’, referring to the conscious effort of moving the physical body with calm and methodical movement. Emphasis on breathwork and integrating the body and mind together. One of the oldest historically recorded styles of Yoga

  2. Vinyasa Yoga (Ashtanga, Iyengar) Vinyasa translates to breath to movement, and this definition encompasses movements in your yoga practice, with music and styles of dancing. By aligning your breast to movement, the yoga practitioner was able to enjoy the meditative state of slowing down and focusing on their inhale and exhale. Typically more energetics than a half a class, this style of power flow eliminates any internal chatter of the brain as you are busy and focused on the breaths that need to be taken while you are moving your body in synchrony. Vinyasa Yoga was developed from the foundation of a Hatha practice, and is often passed down traditionally through conscious repetition. Styles of Vinyasa yoga include Iyengar, ashtanga, and other up-and-coming breath work yoga styles.

  3. Restorative Yoga Restorative Yoga is a practice of poses that is held longer than a typical energetic Yoga class, with the support of props. Longer holds offer deep micro-fascial release in the body, loosens tight muscles and an increase in mental relaxation. Restorative Yoga includes Yin Yoga and Yoga Nidra. Restorative Yoga will often include guided meditation and breathwork.

  4. Hot/Heated Yoga- Heated Yoga ranges from 80-105 degrees F activated by a traditional HVAC system with an optional addition of humidity, using humidifiers to add detoxification. Infrared heat definition here. Reasons for applying heat, calming effect. Consulting with your doctor before trying a heated Yoga class, especially if pregnant, on blood pressure medication, list here. Benefits include making joints more limber, decreased pain, increased flexibility. 

  5. Chair Yoga- Chair yoga is yoga that is practiced from a seat, as well as using a chair as a prop to stretch the body. Rather than holding the limiting belief that yoga can only be practiced with an able body, many practitioners of cherry Yoga are thrilled to know that they can practice yoga from a seat, in a classroom or from their wheelchair. Jeremy Yoga does not mean easy yoga, but rather conscious and intentional movement while from a seat. Practitioners can also place their feet on top of their chair as well as using the back of a chair as a stabilizer to find support when standing and sitting. If recovering from an injury, surgery, or various forms of illness, chair yoga is a great way to find your practice more approachable.

  6. Corporate/Workplace Yoga- Corporate Yoga, our office Yoga, has recently been introduced to bring wellness to the workplace. Your work place may have a health and wellness budget for activities for employees, and have implemented or incentivized you to take a yoga class. Not only does this practice offer mind-body connection, but it also offers community with your coworkers in your workspace. Rather than associating The workplace with stress, incorporating yoga into your workday is a great way to increase productivity and find excitement with something to look forward to as a way to connect with yourself and your coworkers. Corporate Yoga also introduces others to Yoga that otherwise might not try it. Ask your HR department or supervisor if there are any yoga offerings available in your workplace, or expressed interest that you would like to practice yoga in the workplace. A certified yoga teacher will come to you, instead of you traveling to a yoga studio.

  7. Prenatal Yoga- Prenatal yoga indicates yoga that is appropriate for expectant mothers that are in their pregnancy. Once your doctor has approved a yoga practice for you, Yoga can be practiced in any trimester. Your teacher will be well-versed and certified to teach you in prenatal yoga, and show you how to modify your practice. By omitting twists, any poses that require you to lie on your belly, and elevating your heart above baby are some of the accommodations that your teacher will make for you. Many students love prenatal yoga as a way to connect with the baby and enjoy Eliminating from the belief that they are unable to practice yoga during their pregnancy, consult with your doctor and see if physical exercise is right for you!

  8. FUN YOGA- Aerial, SUP Stand Up Paddle Board Yoga, Acro Yoga “pretty fun, but not a Yoga form taught by the masters”- Westernized yoga has introduced many new fun and pop-up boys to practice yoga outside of a traditional yoga studio! Yoga sequences can be practice in aerial silks, from a standup paddleboard, or with another partner which is a style called acro yoga. It’s fun to try something new, as yoga can really be taken with you anywhere. Regardless of where you live in the world or where you are traveling, trying something new like yoga in a unique place and with unique props is a great way to keep this lifelong practice interesting!

title: How to, Maybe, Be Less Indecisive (or Not)
content:
[BORROWED TEMPORARILY FROM https://www.nytimes.com/2019/06/13/smarter-living/how-to-be-less-indecisive.html

Should you order tacos or tikka masala? Stay at the hotel with the free breakfast or the one with all the succulents? Melt into the couch or drag yourself to happy hour?

If you’re like me, even the simplest decisions can make your pulse race. And when it comes to big, life-altering choices, the need to get it right (because life is short!), combined with ever-looming F.O.B.O. (fear of better options), can cause a state of near paralysis.

While this abundance of choice is a result of incredible privilege — not everyone has the freedom to select where they work or live, or how to spend their time or money — it can still be overwhelming. As Barry Schwartz, the author of “The Paradox of Choice,” said, “I’m reasonably confident we’re operating with far, far more options in most parts of our life than we need and that serve us.”

Here are five strategies for spending less time agonizing over decisions and more time appreciating the results:

Go for good enough

Since perfectionism and indecision often go hand in hand, Dr. Schwartz said your first step should be moving from a mind-set that “only the best will do” to “good enough is good enough.”

“In the current world, where choice is virtually unlimited, seeking the best is a recipe for misery,” he said. Instead, he encourages over-thinkers to aim for good enough, whether they’re choosing which job to accept or which cereal to consume.

When setting the good-enough bar, it helps to reflect on your original goal. Did you begin your online shopping odyssey to find a toaster that could clean itself, roast carrots and also charge your cellphone? Or were you just looking for something that would brown your bread?

“We’re seduced into caring about every aspect of the things we’re thinking about,” Dr. Schwartz said, “because all that information is out there for us to evaluate.” Remembering your purpose can simplify the process.

Outsource your decisions

Research has shown that choices sap our willpower and lead to decision fatigue. Which might be why Sheena Iyengar, the author of “The Art of Choosing,” encourages indecisive people to pick their battles — or, in her words, “to be choosy about choosing.”

Do You Suffer From Decision Fatigue?Aug. 17, 2011

When it comes to wine, for example, all Dr. Iyengar wants is a good glass with dinner. So rather than poring over varietals and vintages, she outsources the decision to her local wine store, asking it to send her a case of surprises every few months. “Wine continues to be an actual joyful part of my life because I don’t put in the effort,” she said. “I’m happier when I have fewer decisions to make.”

In addition to leaning on experts, you can share the onus with those around you. When my partner and I make dinner plans with his brother and sister-in-law, no one ever wants to pick the restaurant. So we began taking turns as the designated chooser, allowing each of us to let ourselves off the hook for a jubilant 75 percent of our shared dinners.

For similarly trivial choices, you don’t even need another human. You could rely on habits and routines, like wearing a work uniform or eating a salad for lunch every day, to reserve mental bandwidth for more important decisions. Or you could emulate the man who coined “F.O.B.O” and base your choices on the second hand of your watch.

Employ the ‘90 Percent Rule’

Ever hemmed and hawed over whether to attend a social event or accept a new freelance project? When a yes-or-no decision has ample pros and cons, try the “90 percent rule” from Greg McKeown’s book “Essentialism.”

This involves evaluating an opportunity on a scale from 0 to 100. If your interest falls anywhere below 90 percent, reduce its score to zero and reject it. “It just gets you back to sanity,” Mr. McKeown said. “If it’s not a definite yes, then it can become a definite no. You don’t have to worry about it too much.”

For the aforementioned social event, maybe 80 percent of you thinks it would be fun, but the other 20 percent would rather cuddle with your children. For the freelance gig, maybe 50 percent of you would like the cash, but the other half knows you’re already spread too thin.

This rule makes the decisions easy; because neither is a 90, it’s rejected. “Think about how you’d feel if you scored a 65 on some test,” Mr. McKeown wrote in his book. “Why would you deliberately choose to feel that way about an important choice in your life?”

Why You Should Learn to Say ‘No’ More OftenMay 8, 2017

Create thought experiments

In his popular blog Wait But Why, Tim Urban has advised readers on making major decisions like getting married or picking a career, often using thought experiments as guidance.

Say you’re having doubts about your current relationship, but can’t decide if you should call it quits. Mr. Urban might suggest envisioning a button: Pressing it would propel you into a future two months post-breakup. You would have already had the hard conversations and the overly public subway sob sessions, and your ex’s side of the closet would be empty, nary a stray sock in sight. Would you press it? If the answer is yes, then it’s not the breakup you’re dreading, it’s the pain and hassle that accompany it.

Or, if you’re deciding whether to move across the country, imagine you’ve asked your best friend to choose for you. On the big day, she hands you an envelope; inside, it announces you’re leaving next month. Do you feel excited? Or disappointed?

Using these types of thought experiments to isolate important variables, Mr. Urban said, can help you “cut through fog to see clarity” — and help logic-based thinkers better trust their gut.

Remember it’s just a dot

The road to decisiveness abounds with strategies. You could artificially limit your options, like visiting only three websites when shopping for a new dress. You could make spreadsheets or set a timer. You could pretend you’re giving advice to a friend.

But one of the most important things for recovering un-deciders to realize — and accept — is that they will never have all the information. Referencing Steve Jobs’s famous line that you can connect the dots only looking backward, Mr. Urban urged anyone frozen by indecision to simply pick a “good next dot,” saying, “It doesn’t have to be perfect — it’s just a dot along the way.”

Dr. Schwartz would agree. “The privileged among us live in a world where mostly we’re choosing among really good options,” he said. “And the difference between really good and really, really good is not worth your effort to discern, even when the stakes are high.”

By picking the next dot, and the next one, it will allegedly get easier. Mr. Urban, for the most part, has come out on the other side, having reduced his indecisiveness through years of reflection, journaling and thought experiments.

“Decision making is the steering wheel of your life,” he explained. “And you want to get good at driving.”

title: Privacy Policy
content:
Effective date: February 20, 2023

This Privacy Policy describes Brim Living Inc.’s (“Brim Living” and “Brimming”) policies and procedures on the collection, use and disclosure of Your information when You use the Service and tells You about Your privacy rights and how the law protects You.

We use Your Personal data to provide and improve the Service. By using the Service, You agree to the collection and use of information in accordance with this Privacy Policy.

Definitions

For the purposes of this Privacy Policy:

  • Account

    means a unique account created for You to access our Service or parts of our Service.

  • Affiliate

    means an entity that controls, is controlled by or is under common control with a party, where “control” means ownership of 50% or more of the shares, equity interest or other securities entitled to vote for election of directors or other managing authority.

  • Application

    means the software program provided by the Company downloaded by You on any electronic device, named Brimming

  • Business

    , for the purpose of the CCPA (California Consumer Privacy Act), refers to the Company as the legal entity that collects Consumers’ personal information and determines the purposes and means of the processing of Consumers’ personal information, or on behalf of which such information is collected and that alone, or jointly with others, determines the purposes and means of the processing of consumers’ personal information, that does business in the State of California.

  • Company

    (referred to as either “the Company”, “We”, “Us” or “Our” in this Agreement) refers to Brim Living Inc., San Diego, CA 92120, United States. For the purpose of the GDPR, the Company is a Data Controller.

  • Consumer

    , for the purpose of the CCPA (California Consumer Privacy Act), means a natural person who is a California resident. A resident, as defined in the law, includes (1) every individual who is in the USA for other than a temporary or transitory purpose, and (2) every individual who is domiciled in the USA who is outside the USA for a temporary or transitory purpose.

  • Cookies

    are small files that are placed on Your computer, mobile device or any other device by a website, containing the details of Your browsing history on that website among its many uses.

  • Country

    refers to the United States.

  • Data Controller

    , for the purposes of the GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation), refers to the Company as the legal person which alone or jointly with others determines the purposes and means of the processing of Personal Data.

  • Device

    means any device that can access the Service such as a computer, a cellphone or a digital tablet.

  • Do Not Track

    (DNT) is a concept that has been promoted by US regulatory authorities, in particular the U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC), for the Internet industry to develop and implement a mechanism for allowing internet users to control the tracking of their online activities across websites.

  • Facebook Fan Page

    is a public profile named Brim Living and Brimming specifically created by the Company on the Facebook social network, accessible from

    https://www.facebook.com/brimliving/

  • Personal Data

    is any information that relates to an identified or identifiable individual. For the purposes for GDPR, Personal Data means any information relating to You such as a name, an identification number, location data, online identifier or to one or more factors specific to the physical, physiological, genetic, mental, economic, cultural or social identity. For the purposes of the CCPA, Personal Data means any information that identifies, relates to, describes or is capable of being associated with, or could reasonably be linked, directly or indirectly, with You.

  • Sale

    , for the purpose of the CCPA (California Consumer Privacy Act), means selling, renting, releasing, disclosing, disseminating, making available, transferring, or otherwise communicating orally, in writing, or by electronic or other means, a Consumer’s Personal information to another business or a third party for monetary or other valuable consideration

  • Service

    refers to the Application or the Website or both.

  • Service Provider

    means any natural or legal person who processes the data on behalf of the Company. It refers to third-party companies or individuals employed by the Company to facilitate the Service, to provide the Service on behalf of the Company, to perform services related to the Service or to assist the Company in analyzing how the Service is used. For the purpose of the GDPR, Service Providers are considered Data Processors.

  • Third-party Social Media Service

    refers to any website or any social network website through which a User can log in or create an account to use the Service.

  • Usage Data

    refers to data collected automatically, either generated by the use of the Service or from the Service infrastructure itself (for example, the duration of a page visit).

  • Website

    refers to Brim Living or Brimming, accessible from brimliving.com or brimming.io

  • You

    means the individual accessing or using the Service, or the company, or other legal entity on behalf of which such individual is accessing or using the Service, as applicable. Under GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation), You can be referred to as the Data Subject or as the User as you are the individual using the Service.

Collection and Use of Your Personal Data

Types of Data Collected

Personal Data

While using Our Service, We may ask You to provide Us with certain personally identifiable information that can be used to contact or identify You. Personally identifiable information may include, but is not limited to: first name, last name, email address, phone number, gender, height, weight, birthday/age, location, billing & payment information, login password and usage data.

Usage Data

Usage Data is collected automatically when using the Service.

Usage Data may include information such as Your Device’s Internet Protocol address (e.g. IP address), browser type, browser version, the pages of our Service that You visit, the time and date of Your visit, the time spent on those pages, unique device identifiers and other diagnostic data.

When You access the Service by or through a mobile device, We may collect certain information automatically, including, but not limited to, the type of mobile device You use, Your mobile device unique ID, the IP address of Your mobile device, Your mobile operating system, the type of mobile Internet browser You use, unique device identifiers and other diagnostic data.

We may also collect information that Your browser sends whenever You visit our Service or when You access the Service by or through a mobile device.

While using Our Application, in order to provide features of Our Application, We may collect, with your prior permission:

  • Information regarding your location

  • Information from your Device’s phone book (contacts list)

  • Pictures and other information from your Device’s camera and photo library

We use this information to provide features of Our Service, to improve and customize Our Service. The information may be uploaded to the Company’s servers and/or a Service Provider’s server or it be simply stored on Your device.

You can enable or disable access to this information at any time, through Your Device settings.

Information from Third-Party Social Media Services

The Company allows You to create an account and log in to use the Service through Apple, Facebook, and Google. If You decide to register through or otherwise grant us access to a Third-Party Social Media Service, We may collect Personal data that is already associated with Your Third-Party Social Media Service’s account, such as Your name, Your email address, Your activities or Your contact list associated with that account.

You may also have the option of sharing additional information with the Company through Your Third-Party Social Media Service’s account. If You choose to provide such information and Personal Data, during registration or otherwise, You are giving the Company permission to use, share, and store it in a manner consistent with this Privacy Policy.

Tracking Technologies and Cookies

We use Cookies and similar tracking technologies to track the activity on Our Service and store certain information. Tracking technologies used are beacons, tags, and scripts to collect and track information and to improve and analyze Our Service.

You can instruct Your browser to refuse all Cookies or to indicate when a Cookie is being sent. However, if You do not accept Cookies, You may not be able to use some parts of our Service.

Cookies can be “Persistent” or “Session” Cookies. Persistent Cookies remain on your personal computer or mobile device when You go offline, while Session Cookies are deleted as soon as You close your web browser. Learn more about cookies: All About Cookies.

We use both session and persistent Cookies for the purposes set out below:

Necessary / Essential Cookies Type: Session Cookies Administered by: Us Purpose: These Cookies are essential to provide You with services available through the Website and to enable You to use some of its features. They help to authenticate users and prevent fraudulent use of user accounts. Without these Cookies, the services that You have asked for cannot be provided, and We only use these Cookies to provide You with those services.

Cookies Policy / Notice Acceptance Cookies Type: Persistent Cookies Administered by: Us Purpose: These Cookies identify if users have accepted the use of cookies on the Website.

Functionality Cookies Type: Persistent Cookies Administered by: Us Purpose: These Cookies allow us to remember choices You make when You use the Website, such as remembering your login details or language preference. The purpose of these Cookies is to provide You with a more personal experience and to avoid You having to re-enter your preferences every time You use the Website.

Tracking and Performance Cookies Type: Persistent Cookies Administered by: Third-Parties Purpose: These Cookies are used to track information about traffic to the Website and how users use the Website. The information gathered via these Cookies may directly or indirectly identify you as an individual visitor. This is because the information collected is typically linked to a pseudonymous identifier associated with the device you use to access the Website. We may also use these Cookies to test new advertisements, pages, features or new functionality of the Website to see how our users react to them.

For more information about the cookies we use and your choices regarding cookies, please visit our Cookies Policy.

    to manage Your registration as a user of the Service. The Personal Data You provide can give You access to different functionalities of the Service that are available to You as a registered user.

    the development, compliance and undertaking of the purchase contract for the products, items or services You have purchased or of any other contract with Us through the Service.

  • To contact You:

  • To provide You

    with news, special offers and general information about other goods, services and events which we offer that are similar to those that you have already purchased or enquired about unless You have opted not to receive such information.

  • To manage Your requests:

    To attend and manage Your requests to Us.

We may share your personal information in the following situations:

  • With Service Providers:

    We may share Your personal information with Service Providers to monitor and analyze the use of our Service, to advertise on third party websites to You after You visited our Service, for payment processing, to contact You.

  • For Business transfers:

    We may share or transfer Your personal information in connection with, or during negotiations of, any merger, sale of Company assets, financing, or acquisition of all or a portion of our business to another company.

  • With Affiliates:

    We may share Your information with Our affiliates, in which case we will require those affiliates to honor this Privacy Policy. Affiliates include Our parent company and any other subsidiaries, joint venture partners or other companies that We control or that are under common control with Us.

  • With Business partners:

    We may share Your information with Our business partners to offer You certain products, services or promotions.

  • With other users:

    when You share personal information or otherwise interact in the public areas with other users, such information may be viewed by all users and may be publicly distributed outside. If You interact with other users or register through a Third-Party Social Media Service, Your contacts on the Third-Party Social Media Service may see Your name, profile, pictures and description of Your activity. Similarly, other users will be able to view descriptions of Your activity, communicate with You and view Your profile.

Retention of Your Personal Data

The Company will retain Your Personal Data only for as long as is necessary for the purposes set out in this Privacy Policy. We will retain and use Your Personal Data to the extent necessary to comply with our legal obligations (for example, if we are required to retain your data to comply with applicable laws), resolve disputes, and enforce our legal agreements and policies.

The Company will also retain Usage Data for internal analysis purposes. Usage Data is generally retained for a shorter period of time, except when this data is used to strengthen the security or to improve the functionality of Our Service, or We are legally obligated to retain this data for longer time periods.

Transfer of Your Personal Data

Your information, including Personal Data, is processed at the Company’s operating offices and in any other places where the parties involved in the processing are located. It means that this information may be transferred to — and maintained on — computers located outside of Your state, province, country or other governmental jurisdiction where the data protection laws may differ than those from Your jurisdiction.

Your consent to this Privacy Policy followed by Your submission of such information represents Your agreement to that transfer.

The Company will take all steps reasonably necessary to ensure that Your data is treated securely and in accordance with this Privacy Policy and no transfer of Your Personal Data will take place to an organization or a country unless there are adequate controls in place including the security of Your data and other personal information.

Disclosure of Your Personal Data

Business Transactions

If the Company is involved in a merger, acquisition or asset sale, Your Personal Data may be transferred. We will provide notice before Your Personal Data is transferred and becomes subject to a different Privacy Policy.

Law enforcement

Under certain circumstances, the Company may be required to disclose Your Personal Data if required to do so by law or in response to valid requests by public authorities (e.g. a court or a government agency).

Other legal requirements

The Company may disclose Your Personal Data in the good faith belief that such action is necessary to:

  • Comply with a legal obligation

  • Protect and defend the rights or property of the Company

  • Prevent or investigate possible wrongdoing in connection with the Service

  • Protect the personal safety of Users of the Service or the public

  • Protect against legal liability

Security of Your Personal Data

The security of Your Personal Data is important to Us, but remember that no method of transmission over the Internet, or method of electronic storage is 100% secure. While We strive to use commercially acceptable means to protect Your Personal Data, We cannot guarantee its absolute security.

Information on the Processing of Your Personal Data

Service Providers have access to Your Personal Data only to perform their tasks on Our behalf and are obligated not to disclose or use it for any other purpose.

Analytics

We may use third-party Service providers to monitor and analyze the use of our Service.

Google Analytics

Google Analytics is a web analytics service offered by Google that tracks and reports website traffic. Google uses the data collected to track and monitor the use of our Service. This data is shared with other Google services. Google may use the collected data to contextualize and personalize the ads of its own advertising network.
